### Problem

Set up lsp per instructions, open an Go file in a Go project on neovim HEAD, I see error message:

```
LSP[gopls]: Error SERVER_REQUEST_HANDLER_ERROR: "...eovim/HEAD-0c0be09/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/_watch.lua:100: ENOENT: no such file or directory"
```

### Steps to reproduce

1. install gopls: `go install golang.org/x/tools/gopls@latest`
    ```
    $ gopls version
    golang.org/x/tools/gopls v0.15.2
    ```
2. run the following:
    - `mkdir -p ~/tmp/test-nvim`
    - `cd ~/tmp/test-nvim`
    - `go mod init test-nvim`
    - `go work init`
3. create `test.lua` with content:
    ```lua
    vim.lsp.start({
	    name = "gopls",
	    cmd = { "gopls" },
	    root_dir = vim.fs.dirname(vim.fs.find({ "go.work", "go.mod" }, { upward = true })[1]),
    })
    ```
4. `nvim --clean -u ~/tmp/test-nvim/test.lua main.go`
5. Error shows:

```
LSP[gopls]: Error SERVER_REQUEST_HANDLER_ERROR: "...eovim/HEAD-0c0be09/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/_watch.lua:99: ENOENT: no such fil
e or directory"
```

I put a debug print statement in https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/master/runtime/lua/vim/_watch.lua#L99

```lua
  print(vim.inspect(path))
```

I see the following message:

```
11:09:45 msg_show "/Users/jackieli/tmp/test-nvim"
11:09:45 msg_show "/Users/jackieli/tmp/test-nvim/vendor"
11:09:45 msg_show LSP[gopls]: Error SERVER_REQUEST_HANDLER_ERROR: "...eovim/HEAD-0c0be09/share/nvim/runtime/lua/vim/_watch.lua:100: ENOENT: no such file or directory"
```

I believe the lsp handler is trying to add the folders to the file watch list but my project isn't using Go's 'vendor/' directory, it should skip or fail silently. But it shows the error instead.

This error only starts to show up recently. The LSP related functionality is not affected.

**Note** that this doesn't happen with 0.9.5. Tested with:

`/opt/homebrew/Cellar/neovim/0.9.5/bin/nvim --clean -u ~/tmp/test-nvim/test.lua main.go`

### Expected behavior

No error showing

### Neovim version (nvim -v)

NVIM v0.10.0-dev-2702+g 0c0be09ea Homebrew

### Vim (not Nvim) behaves the same?

N/A

### Operating system/version

macOS 14.2.1

### Terminal name/version

kitty 0.33.1

### $TERM environment variable

xterm-kitty

### Installation

homebrew

This is the final comment I'm gonna make on this issue, but I'm just gonna say this:

Honestly, if this bug was known about beforehand (whether from CI tests, or this issue, etc.) a month+ in-advance, it shouldn't have ever made it into a stable major release (nvim 0.10 stable). Perhaps hiding/censoring comments on this one was not the best idea.

For me, it was happening every single time I edited a new buffer that was configured to use the standard LSP no matter the language/project (which makes sense since it is apart of the default capabilities passed to every lsp server: [see here](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/blob/e20c5fba2c77b7e7ea93363abc987d913e5f9f58/runtime/lua/vim/lsp/protocol.lua#L635)). So what I did is I finally just went in and removed the `didChangeWatchedFiles` capability from the defaults entirely, although it seems to be the underlying libuv file-watcher impl (or, how it's being used/called in nvim, although I doubt that's the issue given the simplicity of the `luv` interface) that is ultimately broken for some reason (and fwiw I'm on macOS not Linux).

Here's the quick & simple solution I came up with if anyone wants to try it (e.g. just put this into your lua vimrc or otherwise `require` and run it during neovim startup):

```lua
-- General/Global LSP Configuration
local api = vim.api
local lsp = vim.lsp

local make_client_capabilities = lsp.protocol.make_client_capabilities
function lsp.protocol.make_client_capabilities()
    local caps = make_client_capabilities()
    if not (caps.workspace or {}).didChangeWatchedFiles then
        vim.notify(
            'lsp capability didChangeWatchedFiles is already disabled',
            vim.log.levels.WARN
        )
    else
        caps.workspace.didChangeWatchedFiles = nil
    end

    return caps
end
```

Personally I don't even understand the point of using a file watcher in neovim when there's already autocmds, `:checktime`, and `'autoread'`? Which would seem to me to already be capable of handling most cases.
